title: JumpCloud API Key leaked via Open Github Repository.
content:
Summary: Open Github Repo Leaking Starbucks JumbCloud API Key
Description:
Team,
While going through Github search I discovered a public repository which contains Jumbcloud API Key of Starbucks.
Repo: https://github.com/██████████/Project.
File: https://github.com/████/Project/blob/0d56bb910923da2fbee95971778923f734a25f68/getSystemUsers.go
Code 39 Bytes
1req.Header.Add("x-api-key", "████████")
POC
List systems ``` curl -H "x-api-key: ████████" "https://console.jumpcloud.com/api/systems"
Code 81 Bytes
1
2* ```
3curl -H "x-api-key: █████" "https://console.jumpcloud.com/api/systemusers"
SSO Applications ```curl -H "x-api-key: ██████" "https://console.jumpcloud.com/api/applications"
Code 301 Bytes
1
2## Impact
3
4This issue impact is critical as through this API anyone could 
5* Execute commands on systems [https://docs.jumpcloud.com/1.0/commands/create-a-command](https://docs.jumpcloud.com/1.0/commands/create-a-command)
6* Add/Remove users which has access to internal systems
7* AWS Account Takeover
steps: Search for public repositories on GitHub containing JumpCloud API keys.
Identify the exposed API key in the repository's source code (e.g., in the file `getSystemUsers.go`).
Use the exposed API key to make unauthorized requests to the JumpCloud API (e.g., list systems, add/remove users, execute commands).
vuln_description: A public GitHub repository was found to contain a hardcoded JumpCloud API key belonging to Starbucks. This key could be used to perform unauthorized actions such as executing commands on systems, modifying user access, and potentially taking over AWS accounts.
reason: The vulnerability was discovered through simple GitHub searches and did not require any complex interactions or manipulations. The exposed API key was easily accessible in the repository's source code.
